title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 17
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: Regular entries were made in thecouncil books, of the expedition to the Newmilne, "where they braived theScottes to come and fecht them, butte the cowardes never appeared."

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 17
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: The device of Hume, in sending them tothe Newmilne, was admired for its ingenuity; and all Berwick rung with thepraises of Hume and his fair spouse.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 17
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: "Ha! traitor!" cried the Mayor, "the device of sending us to Newmilne willnot avail thee.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 17
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: As he went along, his eye fell upon that source of so much contentionbetween the men of Berwick and the border barons, the dam-dike of theNewmilne, and against which the Lord Hume, as well as himself and many ofthe neighbouring knights and lairds, had vowed destruction.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 17
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: The origin of thishatred had some connection with an affair of the Newmilne, belonging toBerwick; the dam-dike of which, Patrick alleged, prevented the salmon fromgetting up the river, and hence destroyed all his angling sport, as well asthat of all the noblemen and gentlemen that resorted to the river for thepurpose of practising the "gentle art."
